title: 'Heartbreaking': Hidden toll of Sydney's wettest August in 27 years
text:
C﻿ountless sporting fields and ovals across Sydney are still underwater following the city's wettest August in 27 years.

The record deluge has come at a high price for young people – weekend sports.

Perpetually soggy grounds have resulted in soccer matches in some areas being rained out for the past month.

Soggy soccer fields across Sydney have resulted in soccer games being cancelled for a month. (9News)

President of Holroyd Soccer Club Danny Rizk told Today it has been a "heartbreaking" few weeks for young players.

"The whole reason we're here is for these kids to to enjoy their sport and get out on the field. And it's it's heartbreaking when we have to tell them, sorry, look, you're not playing," Rizk said.

"That's happened now for four weekends."

"We work extremely hard to keep our kids on the field playing sport, keeping healthy," he added.

"And all this does is just drives them away and keeps them at home on monitors and on screens."

Holroyd Soccer Club President Danny Rizk. (9News)

Rizk said his one of the local fields in Guildford has poor drainage and is a muddy mess after heavy rain over the past few weeks.

He said when 75 per cent of the fields are unplayable, the whole round is cancelled.﻿

The soccer president said synthetic turf is a good way to ensure wet weather doesn't destroy the field.

"﻿It's not the only solution, but it's definitely a solution," he said.

"Having a few more around the area will definitely keep weekends like the ones that we've had in the past four weeks operating, at least moving in our local area,

"We've only got one synthetic field and it's just not enough. We had to play 58 games last weekend. That's as an association and they weren't able to play it."

The torrential rain that battering Sydney also caused a giant sinkhole open up on a sporting oval in Cammeray.

Locals first spotted the sinkhole at Tunks Park on Thursday after another big night of rain.

A sinkhole appeared at Tunks Park on Sydney's north shore. (Nine News)

Fields with poor drainage mean the grounds can stay wet and soggy for weeks. (9News)

The sinkhole was pictured close to the goal posts at the park, which has been completely submerged by water.

Thursday was the wettest day of the year to date for Sydney.

The city's monthly rainfall total reached a record 368.8mm by Friday morning,

Conditions eased on Saturday﻿ and the sun finally made a long-awaited appearance following Sydney's wettest August since 1998.

title: Spirit of Tasmania IV arrives in Hobart amid doubts over company's future
text:
The operator of the Spirit of Tasmania has revealed it may need to be bailed out by the Tasmanian government, with the cost of new boats and ports pushing it to the brink.

TT-Line confirmed its financial woes today as the new Spirit of Tasmania IV finally arrived in Hobart.

Crowds lined the waterfront to get a glimpse of the boat, which is long overdue.

READ MORE: Search for missing Melbourne man in Victorian forest narrows after fresh information

Crowds lined the waterfront to get a glimpse of the boat, which is long overdue. (Nine)

It's one of two ships that will replace the existing fleet that have done the Bass Strait crossing for more than two decades.

They're not only longer and taller but can also accommodate an extra 400 passengers, and have more space for cars, caravans and trucks.

But its journey to Australia has been far from smooth sailing, hailed the biggest infrastructure stuff-up in Tasmania's history.

The ship is too big for the existing berth in Devonport and the new one is still under construction.

So while Spirit of Tasmania IV has been delivered, it won't take passengers until the new berth is ready, about October next year.

They're not only longer and taller but can also accommodate an extra 400 passengers, and have more space for cars, caravans and trucks. (Nine)

"We accept that things could have gone far better," Premier Jeremy Rockliff said.

The new ship will stay in Hobart for the next eight weeks for staff training and to be completely fitted out.

It will then head to Geelong for further testing.

TT-Line then needs to find a location to store it until the new berth is ready.

It's likely it will be held at a Victorian port while Spirit of Tasmania V will stay in Europe until early next year.

But the cost of new ships and berths, including the recently completed Geelong terminal, has pushed TT-Line to the brink.

The ship is too big for the existing berth in Devonport and the new one is still under construction. (Nine)

"We are working with the state government, particularly with the Treasury around the financial position of the company," TT-Line chair Ken Kanofski said.

title: Air guitar world title returns to Finland after 25 years
text:
Finland, the home of the World Air Guitar Championships, has produced its first winner since 2000.

Local hope Aapo "The Angus" Rautio won the 30th edition of a three-day event that brings together competitors from 13 countries.

The final was held on Friday evening on a square in the city of Oulu on Finland's west coast.

Yuta “Sudo-chan” Sudo from Japan was second, with Belgium's Lèon "Leonfire" Ostrowsky named as the audience favourite.

Contestants are judged on the performance of two songs in two separate rounds, each lasting 60 seconds, with the singers pretending to play an imaginary guitar.

Heidi "Pink Passion" Toivio of Finland performs in Oulu. (AP: Eeva Riihela/Lehtikuva)

Passion is a must, but much of the rest is up to the contenders.

Props and costumes are allowed, but backup bands and real instruments are off-limits.

The two-hour final pitted last year's winner, Canada's Zachary "Ichabod Fame" Knowles, against eight national champions and seven contenders who emerged from the qualifying rounds.

The challengers include US champion Saladin "Six String Sal" Thomas and German champion Patrick "Van Airhoven" Culek.

Aapo "The Angus" Rautio won the title, marking Finland’s first win since 2000. (AP: Eeva Riihela/Lehtikuva)

The winner is chosen by a five-member jury of performing arts professionals.

The champion takes home an actual guitar — a "Flying Finn" made by Finnish luthier Matti Nevalainen.

The championships were first held in 1996.

Organisers say that "according to the competition ideology, wars will end, climate change will stop and all bad things will vanish when all the people in the world play the air guitar".

Patrick "Van Airhoven" Culek of Germany. (AP: Eeva Riihela/Lehtikuva)

Contestants may, according to the rules, "use an electric or an acoustic air guitar, or both".

The jury takes into account "originality, the ability to be taken over by the music, stage presence, technical merit, artistic impression and airness".

Each jury member scores the performances with a mark between 4.0 and 6.0.

Each contestant's scores from the first and second round — the first with a song chosen by the performer and the second with one chosen by the organisers — are added together and the candidate with the highest total score wins.

AP

title: As Nat Fyfe plays to keep AFL finals dream alive, his junior club does too
text:
As the Fremantle Dockers prepare for today's do-or-die clash with the Western Bulldogs, the childhood club of one of its most celebrated stars is playing to keep its finals dreams alive too.

The Ongerup Football Association (OFA), deep in WA's southern grain belt, has produced its fair share of AFL greats over the years.

However, for the Lake Grace-Pingrup Bombers, 300 kilometres south-east of Perth, there is none as revered or decorated as dual-Brownlow medallist, Nat Fyfe.

In his final season before retirement, Fyfe and his Dockers teammates are chasing the premiership title that has eluded both player and club.

A win today would keep that dream alive.

Nat Fyfe started playing junior football in Lake Grace. (AAP Image: Tony McDonough)

A tale of two teams

But as the ball bounces down in Victoria for what could be Fyfe's last game, the hometown team where he started his football journey are hoping for a win of their own.

"It's the Bombers vs the Bombers; Lake Grace-Pingrup versus Boxwood Hill," Lake Grace-Pingrup club president Chris Poot said.

"It will be a tight tussle, but I'd like to think we can come away with the win and push through to the preliminary final."

Chris Poot hopes both the Dockers and Bombers can keep their finals hopes alive. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding.)

Lake Grace-Pingrup, the league's reigning champions who sit third on the OFA ladder, will play at the same time as the Dockers.

Poot said the shared fate of both teams wasn't lost on locals.

"It's pretty serendipitous or coincidental, but it's definitely one of those things that's sort of dawning on us as well," he said.

"We're all rooting for Nat and the Dockers tomorrow, so that Nat goes one more, and we'll be giving it our all tomorrow as well."

More than 800 people came to watch the semi-finals on Saturday. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding.)

While it may not have been the tens of thousands who bought tickets for the Dockers game in Melbourne, hundreds of people from across the Great Southern flocked to watch their local teams compete yesterday.

Poot, who will run on in today's semi-final, said regardless of the outcome, Fyfe's legacy among the hometown faithful had already been secured.

"We just love seeing him run around, and there's a lot of support and love there for him as well," he said.

" It's fantastic, it just makes us all proud…[Fyfe] gives our kids aspiration. "

A banner hung from the Lake Grace pub celebrates Nat Fyfe's first Brownlow Medal win. (ABC Great Southern)

Following in Fyfe's footsteps

Those aspirations are already coming to the fore with a crop of the club's promising young players making their mark in the junior league.

Under 13s player Darcey Pelham, named fairest and best for the league this year, said Fyfe, along with other local players who made it to the AFL, showed young players what could be achieved.

"It's pretty good to have someone like that come from my town," he said.

"He's just so explosive, how good he used to be; the Brownlows, all the Brownlows he's won."

Darcy Pelham hopes to one day make it to the AFL. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding )

Pelham, who was instrumental in his team's 97-16 semi-final win over the Gnowangerup Bulldogs on Saturday, said he hoped to follow in the footsteps of his former clubmate.

"We played a lot better than last week. Now we're going into the finals and we know we can beat them," he said.

His plan is to move to Claremont Football Club in Perth.

"I'll try my hardest from there to try and get drafted," he said.

Along with Fyfe, Lake Grace-Pingrup has produced several former AFL players including Mark Bairstow and the Moreton brothers: Cale, Mitch and Jarryd.

Its current crop of players included West Coast's Liam Baker and AFLW player Belinda Smith.

Andrew Lewis says playing conditions in the county produces top grade players. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding.)

'Full on football'

Juniors coach Andrew Lewis said the hard style of football played in the county was one of the defining qualities of its successful players.

"They come into a style of football pretty early in their years, that a lot of the suburban football leagues, they don't tend to play the grade of football that we do as a junior footy side," he said.

"They're exposed to some pretty full-on football early in their years, so they come along really well.

The club has a number of junior players who are earmarked to make it to the next level. (ABC Great Southern: Andrew Chounding)

He said, along with Pelham, there were several other junior players the club had its eye on that could follow in the footsteps of the likes of Fyfe and Smith and make their way to the AFL.

"There's a lot of talent … they are sort of half a dozen, I reckon, around the association, they could definitely go further," he said.

title: Live: Giants aiming to lock in finals spot before Dogs-Dockers blockbuster
text:
The GWS Giants host St Kilda at the Sydney Showgrounds as one of four separate teams who require a win to seal their spot in the top eight for the AFL finals.

Later, the Western Bulldogs face off against Fremantle from 3:15pm (all times AEST), with the loser of that clash at risk of missing out on the top eight.

In Sunday's final match, the Brisbane Lions host Hawthorn at the Gabba from 7:20pm, with the Hawks needing a win to secure their finals spot.

There are also four AFLW matches on, starting with Richmond's clash with the Western Bulldogs at Princes Park from 12:35pm.

Later on Sunday, North Melbourne hosts Port Adelaide at Arden Street from 1:05pm, while Essendon will look to build on a big win last week when it hosts West Coast at Windy Hill from 2:35pm. The final match of Round 2 sees Adelaide host Geelong at Unley Oval from 3:05pm.

Follow the live blog below, keep up to date with all the latest stats in our ScoreCentre, and tune in to our live radio coverage.

Key Events GWS vs STK team news: No late changes for either side 22 minutes ago AFL Sunday live scoreboard C By Chris De Silva A deep dive into the Bulldogs-Dockers blockbuster C By Chris De Silva Pumped for this afternoon's clash between the Western Bulldogs and Fremantle? This yarn from Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson is the perfect preview for you as they break down all the big numbers involving the two teams. Key numbers that will settle the epic Bulldogs-Dockers season finale A cool bit of symmetry involving Nat Fyfe C By Chris De Silva Fremantle superstar Nat Fyfe is essentially playing to extend his AFL career this afternoon. In a wonderful little twist, Fyfe's home town team, the Lake Grace-Pingrup Bombers, will also take the field around the same time as the Dockers to keep their own finals hopes alive! As Nat Fyfe plays to keep AFL finals dream alive, his junior club does too How could today's action shape the top eight? If the Giants beat St Kilda first up, they rise to 64 points, however due to their percentage (115.5), they are likely to finish no higher than fifth. Brisbane, currently fourth, will finish with 66 points to go third on the ladder with a win over Hawthorn tonight. If the Hawks win, they rise to 64 points and their superior percentage of 122.7 would see them rise to fourth on the ladder. Then that Dogs-Dockers match. If the Bulldogs win, they will go to 60 points and due to their percentage of 140.3, could rise as high as fifth. Fremantle would rise to 64 points with a win, but are unlikely to finish any higher than sixth due to their percentage of 108.6. I hope that all makes sense Bailey! title: Double eagles help Lee draw level with hometown hero at Canadian Open
text:
The eagle has landed — twice — to help Australian golfer Minjee Lee soar to a share of the lead at the Canadian Women's Open.

Lee wasn't the only player to go on a scoring tear, with Canadian Brooke Henderson also holing out for eagle from a greenside bunker on the short par-4 17th to the delight of her large partisan gallery.

Both Lee and Henderson carded six-under 65s in the third round at the Mississaugua Golf and Country Club to sit at 11-under 202, sharing a handy three-shot buffer over their nearest challengers going into the final round.

Lee chipped in for birdie on the par-4 eighth, then made a long eagle putt on the par-5 12th. She ran in an eight-footer for another eagle on the 17th, then chipped in again to save par on the par-4 18th.

"I would say those two [eagles] are my highlights and, obviously, the chip-in on the last," Lee said.

"There are no pictures on the scorecard."

Lee won the KPMG Women's PGA Championship in Texas in June for her third major title and 11th LPGA Tour title, and is currently ranked No.4 in the world.

"I think it will just be extra exciting being in the final group with Brooke," the 29-year-old Australian said.

Canada's Brooke Henderson currently shares the lead with Lee following the third round. (Getty Images: Vaughn Ridley)

Henderson, the 2018 champion at Wascana in Saskatchewan, had an eagle, six birdies and two bogeys in breezy and cloudy conditions on Saturday.

The local favourite won the last of her 13 LPGA Tour titles in January 2023.

"It's always been a really special week," Henderson said.

"I feel like I've learned so much every single year playing in it.

"I was just trying to lean back on some times when I've had a lot of success here, what I did and the mentality I had going into it."

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Japan's Akie Iwai, the Portland Classic winner last week who took a three-stroke lead into the weekend, bogeyed the first three holes in a 72 to drop into a tie for third at eight under with top-ranked Jeeno Thitikul, of Thailand.

Thitikul, who shot a third-round 69, is making her first start since taking the No.1 spot in the world from American Nelly Korda.

Australian Grace Kim (71, 69, 67) is in a four-way tie for seventh place at six under.

Aphrodite Deng, a 15-year-old Canadian amateur who was tied for second after an opening 66, was also at six under after a 68.

"It's been incredible with all the people out here supporting me," Deng said.

Korda was tied for 24th at three under after a 72.

AAP

title: Young musicians go behind the scenes to drive next wave of festivals
text:
Energy vibrates through a small town backyard shed as a young band jams, inspired by classic Aussie hard rock.

Temperate, whose members rehearse in Coramba in northern New South Wales, is preparing to perform at an upcoming all-ages live music event at Coffs Harbour.

The Coastal Grown event, which is being curated and delivered by a group of young people from the region, will feature aspiring local bands.

It is the culmination of pilot project Outset by the state's music body, MusicNSW.

The aim is to boost opportunities for regional musicians while also supporting Australia's music festival industry, which has struggled in recent years.

Temperate guitarist, 21-year-old Scott Shrimpton, is part of the 10-member Outset youth committee running the event.

Scott Shrimpton plays guitar with band Temperate during a jam session at Coramba. (ABC News: Charles Rushforth)

"It's such a crucial part for us as Temperate to know how to reach out to people and how to put this live event together, not just for us, but for other musicians as well," he said.

"We are just five young kids coming from the Coffs Coast trying to make a bigger name, and share what we love to do.

"It's amazing to see there are other people like that, even in our community."

MusicNSW program manager Caitlin McGregor said the committee members, all aged 15 to 25, were receiving hands-on experience in every aspect of event planning while being mentored by industry experts.

The Outset youth committee meets with project manager Andrew Davis. (Supplied: MusicNSW)

Ms McGregor said MusicNSW hoped to eventually expand the program across NSW.

"We want to make sure we are giving young people the skills to eventually put on their own DIY events and all-ages events," she said.

"We feel like that's something that has really limited capacity at the moment across NSW.

"So, we think equipping this next generation we'll be able to change that festival environment, and the way people are experiencing and getting involved in music."

Sam Duff is a member of the Outset youth committee and also plays drums. (Supplied: Sam Duff)

Port Macquarie's Sam Duff is also part of the youth committee.

The 17-year-old is used to being on stage as a drummer and hopes to study at Sydney's Conservatorium of Music.

"It's really fascinating to look from the other side and discover how music festivals are run; they seem very simple for someone who buys a ticket and turns up, but there's so much that goes into it," he said.

"We spent a day planning, picked our bands, toured the venue, chose names … we also worked with well-known graphic designers, figured out what our posters and social media would look like."

'Festival band camp'

The Young Gums band performs at this year's Gum Ball festival at Dashville. (Supplied: Earth Sea and Sound Photography)

A similar music festival training program runs in conjunction with the annual Gum Ball music festival at Dashville in the Hunter Valley.

The festival's founder, Matt Johnston, said the program, Young Gums, started after the COVID-19 pandemic to increase opportunities for up-and-coming musicians and boost their waning engagement with teenagers.

"The Young Gums is a five-day mentorship where we get a lot of the performers from the festival, a lot of local professional musicians with different skill sets, and they sit in with 10 kids [aged 13-17] from regional NSW," he said.

"They write songs, and on the last day of the festival they all come together and form a band.

"It's an incredible thing to witness these kids evolve and come out of their shell.

"They see what's achievable and they have a sense of ownership and feel part of the festival."

Rex Wardle and Neve Scully perform as part of Young Gums. (ABC News: Anthony Scully)

Young Gums musical director Laura Sands said this year's event in April was another success.

"This is pretty much a band camp for festivals," she said.

"This is the fifth year, and the kids are smashing it."

Laura Sands and Christopher Dale are mentoring young people. (ABC News: Anthony Scully)

Mr Johnston, 42, said it was crucial the next generation was equipped with the skills needed to run music festivals.

"I have been doing the festival for 20 years," he said.

" It's nice for us to know there are young people there to take the baton and be part of it in the future. "

Music industry hopes

Australian Festival Association managing director Olly Arkins said it was encouraging to see programs like Outset and Young Gums as the festival industry started to regain confidence after the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Dashville Skyline music festival has drawn crowds. (Supplied: Dashville Skyline)

"In 2025 we have seen the sector turn a corner. From a ticket sales perspective and anecdotally, it feels a lot more positive," they said.

"We are still needing to ensure grassroots festivals are starting … so we have that pipeline of talent and audience coming through."

title: Teacher turns sewing hobby into social media business
text:
As the rhythmic sound of Domenica Tootell's sewing machine fills her studio, each loading of the bobbins and stitch change is captured by a simple yet sophisticated video camera set-up.

She is among a growing cohort of creatives who have turned to social media as a means to educate others, and earn an income, from home.

But Mrs Tootell is not new to the online business world.

Her passion for sewing began when she moved to Loxton in 2007 to teach in South Australia's Riverland.

Domenica Tootell showcases different machines used in her sewing video content. (ABC Riverland: Stephanie Nitschke)

Though she was new to the practice, she says she took to the creative activity like a fish to water.

"When I was in high school I really enjoyed woodwork. Sewing wasn't available at my particular school, so anything that was to do with making things with my hands, I really enjoyed," she said.

In 2013, while on maternity leave after having her daughter, Elyse, Mrs Tootell turned her hobby into an online business.

"I put everything together about what I love doing: teaching, sewing, learning," she said.

"I'm a visual learner, so it just happened that making a website and a YouTube channel teaching people how to sew was what seemed to work for me."

Domenica Tootell uses social media to teach others how to sew. (ABC Riverland: Stephanie Nitschke)

Humble beginnings

The success of her online business has allowed Mrs Tootell to take a break from the classroom this year.

"I still work two days a week running playgroups … and doing some relief teaching work here and there," she said.

" The business is gradually becoming the main hustle, and makes my weekdays more flexible. "

Mrs Tootell has come a long way from being a beginner herself.

"The first thing I made that I was really proud of was a little welcome applique block," she said.

"I remember taking it to work one day to show a lady there who was really into quilting.

"I thought, 'She's going to be so impressed with this' [but] she looked at it and said, 'What did you cut your fabric with?'

" The cutting lines that were supposed to be straight were not straight, because I just cut them with normal scissors. "

Sewing shears are a popular choice to make sure fabric is cut clean. (ABC Riverland: Stephanie Nitschke)

Some 12 years on, her YouTube follower count hit 210,000, with more than 21.7 million views across her top 10 videos.

"It's … something that's grown slowly. It just feels like something I do now," she said.

" It's something that I still learn a lot from, watching videos. "

How-to boom

Today, online how-to content is available for almost everything on creator platforms including YouTube and TikTok.

Charles Sturt University senior communications lecturer Travis Holland said social media had democratised content creation to allow people to both produce and distribute it, and access it from an audience perspective.

Travis Holland says social media has disrupted traditional content creation. (Supplied: Travis Holland)

"We are seeing people, for example, in regional areas being able to build those global audiences despite being outside the sort of traditional circuits of capital and influence that we might have seen previously," he said.

" You don't have to be in Sydney anymore to be at the centre of Australia's cultural industries, you can be in a regional town. "

Dr Holland said the medium stood out to people looking to turn hobbies into businesses, and despite a drop-off post-pandemic, the number of creators had continued to grow.

"The trajectory is only [going] up," he said.

"If you can have an audience of even 2,000 people who are regular viewers and engage with your content, but they're scattered all over the world, that's something that would never have flown on traditional media."

Domenica Tootell has updated her home sewing room to have storage space for all her supplies. (ABC Riverland: Stephanie Nitschke)

A new space for growing passion

Dr Holland said authenticity was a major drawcard for audiences engaging in online educational content.

"You actually have to be interested in the thing you're producing content around in order for other people who are in that space to trust you," he said.

"And so we get creatives like sewing instructors representing the shift from traditional craft education, that might have happened in community centres, to this personalised on-demand learning."

Domenica Tootell now has a dedicated workspace for sewing. (ABC Riverland: Stephanie Nitschke)

Mrs Tootell's online success has allowed her to establish a bigger creative space to continue to film her sewing content.

"In the past I've really just worked from our little office in the house … it was very hard to create in there," she said.

"Having a nice, big space just makes it easier. I can have a couple of projects on the go if I want to as well, and I've got a dedicated workspace to go into now."

title: 14yo 'leadfoot' hopes to take WA's burnout scene by storm
text:
As the dust from a smoking set of tyres settles, a 14-year-old girl steps out of the haze.

Clutching a nitrous bottle plush toy and a black and yellow number plate marked SKIDZZZ, Briella Scantlebury hopes to show young women they can claim their place on the pad.

From the town of Harvey, south of Perth, Briella had been begging her parents for a skid car for months, after being exposed to the sport at the Collie Motorplex.

Briella Scantlebury's birthday skid car was completed with a personalised licence plate for the sport. (ABC South West WA: Pip Waller)

"It was the morning of my 14th birthday and I was opening my presents when my parents told me to walk outside," Briella said.

"And there it was, sitting out there on a trailer.

" It was probably one of the best birthdays I've ever had — getting a bloody skid car. "

Briella's stepdad Damien Shaw modified a Holden Commodore V6 ute to ensure it was appropriate for burnout competitions.

Those competing in the sport are judged based on their ability to perform controlled manoeuvres, with points awarded for smoke volume and driving skill.

Mr Shaw said Briella was a "leadfoot" the moment she got behind the wheel.

"She's not one of these kids where you have to turn around and say you need to push the accelerator harder," Mr Shaw said.

"She pretty much bashed it to the limiter straight away.

" Instead of her sitting on her phone and scrolling through videos of other people doing it, now she can do it herself. "

Briella Scantlebury took part in an Open Pad Skids event at the Collie Motorplex in August. (ABC South West WA: Pip Waller)

Behind the wheel at 14?

In order to compete, Briella needs a special licence issued by the Australian Auto-Sport Alliance.

She can drive only with parental permission and needs to have someone over 18 years old in the car with her.

Mr Shaw said both the cars and venues were fully prepared to cope in the event of an incident.

Damien Shaw says his stepdaughter's reaction was "gold" when she first got behind the wheel of her new skid car. (ABC South West WA: Pip Waller)

"The car has a fire extinguisher inside it and the skid pad itself has fire marshals and ambulance crew," he said.

"Helmets are mandatory and we've gone a little bit above with Briella and bought her a fire suit even though she doesn't need one."

Briella said it was "pretty out of sorts" to be a 14-year-old girl competing in the motorsport, and she hoped to show other girls there was a place for them too.

Briella Scantlebury and Damien Shaw work on modifying their Commodore together. (ABC South West WA: Pip Waller)

"There's some people out there that hate on the sport and they think it's just not good enough," Briella said.

"But I find it really interesting how people just like tip in really fast and swing the car and create lots of smoke.

" Girls can do the same amount of things boys can do. If you don't like it, you don't like it, but if you do, you may as well get into it. "

Challenging the 'hoon' stereotype

Briella is aiming to take part in a burnout competition by the end of 2025.

A number of events are held in regional WA, including in Bunbury, Collie, Waroona and Albany.

Chloe Wojtowicz, who helps organise the Bunbury Burnout Challenge, said she had seen a "huge climb" in drivers of all genders over the past decade.

"At some comps there's usually a ladies class, prizes for the best lady driver and they often out-drive the boys," Ms Wojtowicz said.

"Not only are you having a bit of fun and getting comfortable testing the limits, but you're also learning defensive driving as well."

Chloe Wojtowicz says interest in the burnout scene has skyrocketed in the past decade. (ABC South West WA: Pip Waller)

Ms Wojtowicz said those involved in the sport were working hard to challenge negative stereotypes.

"When people hear a loud car they obviously think bogans, ferals, that kind of thing," she said.

"But at the end of the day we're all people that love that horsepower, the loud sounds, the loud music and the fun nights."

title: Belgian star recovers from horror crash to claim first stage of La Vuelta
text:
Sprint ace Jasper Philipsen has bounced back from the crash that prematurely ended his Tour de France, leaving him with a broken collarbone and ribs, as he sprinted to victory on the opening stage of La Vuelta a Espana.

With the great Spanish race making its first ever start in Italy, the star Belgian speedster claimed the red jersey after comfortably outpacing his nearest challengers in Novara following a textbook lead-out from his Alpecin-Deceuninck team in Saturday's (Sunday AEST) bunch finish.

Briton Ethan Vernon, of Israel-Premier Tech, was second and Venezuelan Orluis Aular, of Movistar, came home third, but neither looked close to upsetting the 27-year-old Philipsen, the quickest man in the peloton right now, as he eased to his 14th Grand Tour stage win.

On the largely flat 186.1km ride from Turin to Novara, which had previously hosted two Giro d'Italia finishes, six riders formed a breakaway and opened up a two-minute lead.

Burgos Burpellet's Hugo de la Calle launched a solo attack with 83km to go but he was caught by the peloton with 38km left before the teams set the stage up for the sprint finish which Philipsen finished off with aplomb.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Philipsen, who had also taken the yellow jersey at last month's Tour before a third-stage crash ended up ruling him out of the race, enthused: "Winning is always a nice feeling and definitely when there is a reward like the red jersey, of course it's a nice present.

"We managed to do our lead-out the way we wanted to. In the final kilometre, they executed it perfectly. I saw 175 meters to go and had to start sprinting, I'm really happy it worked out for us.

"After my crash in the Tour, I was really disappointed to be out, it was a setback. This was a nice goal, but I knew we only had one chance because there aren't many opportunities for a sprinter like me at this Vuelta."

Nine of the 10-strong Australian contingent, headed by world road race silver medallist Ben O'Connor (Jayco AlUla) and former Giro d'Italia champ Jai Hindley (Red Bull-BORA-hansgrohe), safely negotiated the opening day.

But Jay Vine (UAE Team Emirates) had a bad day, bringing up the rear of the field nearly three-and-a-half minutes adrift.

AAP

title: Fast fashion undermines op shop efforts to keep stuff out of landfill
text:
Graeme Kendall rarely misses the opportunity to snap up a bargain.

He has been a loyal customer at his local tip shop for years and regularly digs out hidden treasures.

In an increasingly throwaway society, tip shops and second-hand stores are playing a vital role in keeping rubbish out of landfill.

However, as consumers turn toward e-commerce retailers like Shein and Temu that sell items at a very low cost, second-hand stores are being overwhelmed with donations of poor quality.

The Reviva Centre in Noosa recycles all kinds of household items, giving them a second life. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

Finding quality items at a low price comes with the territory for experienced tip-shoppers like Mr Kendall.

Visits have not been as frequent since the retiree had a procedure on his eye last year.

"When I was right, about 12 months ago, I would come here every four to six weeks," he said.

"You'd find stuff here all the time. I got really wrapped up one day and I bought a spa bath.

"I haven't put it in yet but I've cut the hole in the deck so I can just walk out of my bedroom and get in the spa bath under the stars."

More than 7,000 mattresses were recycled at the Reviva Centre last financial year. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

Providing a second life

The local tip shop and second-hand stores have long been ingrained in Australian society, giving household items and clothing a second life.

The Reviva Centre, based in Noosa, plays a crucial role in keeping items out of landfill.

Site manager Mitchell McIntyre said they had noticed an increase in sales over the past few years, and he suspected it was due to the cost-of-living crisis.

Mitchell McIntyre says he still gets surprised by some of the things that come through the store. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

People had told him they would normally go to big hardware stores, but these days, "They're coming to us first," he said.

" Anything from hardware, wood to furniture, we're probably 10 to 20 per cent of the price — if it's in good condition — of the Bunnings equivalent. "

Trips to the tip have allowed Mr Kendall to save more than a penny or two.

"Thousands and thousands and thousands, mate," he chuckled.

"You've gotta walk around and see things and you use your imagination."

The Reviva Centre, a not-for-profit, diverted more than 270 tonnes of waste last financial year and served more than 23,000 customers.

The Reviva Centre rehomed more than 277 tonnes of household items in the past financial year. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

Mr McIntyre admitted he had raised an eyebrow at a few things that had come through the facility.

"I can't say the strangest thing I've seen as it's a little bit X-rated, but we've had some really amazing stuff like full-on boats that we can only just fit in the yard," he said.

"Lately, we're averaging around 500 to 600 recycled mattresses every month. You can imagine 8,000 mattresses piled up in landfill.

"We have guys here that will strip the mattress, take the steel out, get the foam out of it, and the foam will go down to Clark Rubber and be recycled into underlay.

"It's saving a lot."

Fast fashion crippling progress

While some consumers are turning to a sustainable approach of using recycled goods to save money, experts argue the progress made is likely being cancelled out by the rise of online fast-fashion stores.

University of the Sunshine Coast international business educator and researcher Jacqueline Burgess said there was a tug of war taking place among young consumers.

Jacqueline Burgess warns single-use clothing from fast-fashion retailers voids the rise in second-hand consumers. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

Dr Burgess said while people aged between 18 and 35 were more likely to shop at a second-hand store than any other demographic, they were also the biggest consumers of fast-fashion retailers.

"While sustainability is important and a factor there somewhere, it seems like it's more low cost that is driving this," she said.

" The issue is: if you can buy it new for $5 why are you going to spend $4 at a second-hand store? "

Low-cost e-commerce retailers provide an option for consumers grappling with rising costs. (Reuters: Dado Ruvic)

Online retailer Shein recorded more than $1.2 billion in sales in the Australian market last financial year and it has set off a chain reaction.

Dr Burgess said Shein's business model of low cost, low risk and fast delivery was creating a market for single-use clothing, wreaking havoc on local businesses.

"There is less reusable clothing coming through because Shein has designed clothing that can be worn once," Dr Burgess said.

"Op shops are being absolutely drowned in donations but unfortunately the quality of those donations is decreasing, which then goes into landfill."

The 18-35-year-old demographic is the most likely to buy second-hand goods. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jessica Ross)

Dr Burgess said the cost-of-living crisis was aiding fast fashion and that unless stricter regulations were implemented, online retailers were here to stay.

"Secondhand stores are binning huge amounts of donations because they don't have the energy, time or resources to repair anything," she said.

"It's a real cycle of problems happening here."

title: Hobart skaters petition for park rebuild as wheels 'get stuck in cracks'
text:
It was the most bizarre thing skater Paul McMacken had ever seen.

Each week, 50 to 100 girls were turning up to the skate park in North Hobart to learn how to skateboard.

"I'd speak to people all over the country and they couldn't understand what was going on in Hobart," he said.

"I mean, it was a sport that was always male-dominated worldwide."

Paul McMacken coaches the next generation of Tasmanian talent, running She Shreds sessions and high-performance training for Hobart skaters. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Mr McMacken said the surge in female skaters during the 2010s came when father-of-two Jared Andrews started the organisation 'She Shreds', to give local girls a safe opportunity to try skating.

"Before She Shreds started, I probably could have named the one or two, three girls in Tasmania who skated," Mr McMacken said, as president of the organisation.

" And now there's thousands of them. "

North Hobart Skate Park was built in 2002, quickly becoming a central spot for the local scene. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Eleven years on, skaters say She Shreds deserves a facility that can further ramp up their skaters' success.

The petition to Hobart Council and the Tasmanian government says an upgrade will level the playing field for local athletes. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

An online petition with more than 1,000 signatures lists annoyances at North Hobart Skate Park, including cracks and a lack of lights or shelter.

It also envisions more modern obstacles to restore the renown the park enjoyed in the 2000s.

Hobart City Council occasionally repairs damage but can't keep up with the facility's age, skaters report. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Gen Alpha skaters reach for greater heights

Fifteen-year-old Zailee Jackson has skated for five years. She Shreds sessions and high-performance groups with Mr McMacken helped her find her bearings.

"It would be pretty cool to become a professional skateboarder," she said.

" But it's a bit hard down here in Tassie to get to that good of a level. "

Zailee Jackson has visited visited skate parks on the mainland that allow for more advanced training. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

She said other states had more advanced and better-maintained skate parks.

"A lot of the concrete is falling apart so it makes it a bit tricky to dodge the holes in the concrete," she said about North Hobart Skate Park.

" Sometimes when I'm doing tricks, my wheels will get stuck in one of the little gaps or cracks. "

'Vert ramps' in Hobart are only half the height of those found in high-level skate parks. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Next year, She Shreds will be forced to vacate their shed and find a new home. They also rely on public facilities like North Hobart Skate Park.

Mr McMacken said it was time for governments to back young Tasmanian skaters with adequate facilities.

"I think they need to understand now it's an Olympic sport, we've got skaters down here that could be competing on the world stage."

She Shreds will be forced to leave their shed in Melville Street next year, the premises up for sale by the University of Tasmania. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Tokyo 2020 Olympian Grace Cochrane spent several years with She Shreds.

"She could have continued if she had the opportunities. It was pretty hard for her," Mr McMacken said.

Nostalgic skaters hesitant to erase history

Louis Carney's daughter Iris now contributes to the legacy of the skate park, affectionately known as Elizabeth College Skate Park, or EC. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Skater Louis Carney has documented the history of the park from its beginnings.

"It is more than just concrete and it's so deeply embedded with decades of history, stories and community identity," he said.

Mr Carney recently returned to skating and makes a point to bring his daughter to the North Hobart Skate Park next to Elizabeth College (EC).

" We'll drive 45 minutes to go to EC and we'll drive past three skate parks on the way. You want to be at EC because it's the hub. "

North Hobart Skate Park is imprinted with memories for multiple generations of skaters. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

He was shocked to see the state of the park but suggested rolling current features into any new design.

"I think a full demolition would be harsh and culturally insensitive," he said.

"It's critical that the council and the designers work closely with the local skate community."

The right facility for a diverse community

Harrison Mol co-organised the petition to upgrade the skate park near Elizabeth College, affectionately known as EC Skate Park. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

"If you come down here on a weekend or during peak times, it is packed. It's still obviously a highly valued location," lifelong skater Harrison Mol said.

"However, it's no longer up to the standard that it should be," Mr Mol said.

Mr Mol said planners should work with everyone involved to get a better facility.

"Whether that's doing a complete redo or trying to preserve some of the features of the skate park that are important and are of historical relevance."

Harrison Mol has travelled extensively as a skater and seen large investments into skate parks on the mainland. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Mr Mol said She Shreds was an initiative he had not seen the likes of elsewhere in Australia.

"We should be building this skate park for She Shreds."

The Hobart City Council is currently working on renewing its lease over the Crown land where the North Hobart Skate Park is located, according to David Reeve, the council's director infrastructure and assets network.

The Hobart City Council maintains North Hobart Skate Park. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

"When the lease is resolved — pending both ministerial and council approval — plans will be developed to renew the skate park as part of broader sport and recreation priorities," Mr Reeve said.

"In the meantime, while the facility is nearing the end of its useful life, council continues to carry out regular maintenance, including routine inspections and repairs to ensure the park remains safe and usable."

title: Operator says business will go under if SA dive site doesn't reopen
text:
Divers and tourism operators are lobbying the South Australian government to secure the remnants of the Rapid Bay jetty in the state's south-east so the world-class dive site beneath can be reopened.

They have been unable to access the site since a 20-metre exclusion zone for all swimmers and boats was placed around the remaining sections of the jetty in June, after it was further damaged by storms.

The original jetty was constructed in the 1940s by BHP and was used to load limestone from an adjacent quarry.

At 488m long with a 200m T-section at the end, it fell into disrepair in the 1990s and was closed to pedestrians in 2004.

However, it remained an important site for marine life and divers.

A concerted effort by residents to ensure the community was not left without a jetty resulted in a new Rapid Bay jetty being constructed and opened in 2009, with the old jetty structure remaining in place.

Fear dive business will go under

Peter Corrigan has been diving since 1986 and is one of several tourism operators who conduct underwater tours at Rapid Bay.

Peter Corrigan, runs Sea Dragon Dive Lodge, says the old jetty can be repaired. (Supplied: Peter Corrigan)

He said if the area underneath the old jetty was not made safe and the site reopened, his business, which was already suffering due to the state's algal bloom, would go under.

Mr Corrigan said it was obvious the storm damage had made the jetty more dangerous to dive under, but any parts posing a danger could be removed or secured.

"It can be repaired and made safe for divers again," he said.

" It's one of the best dives in the world. That's no exaggeration. "

The damaged old Rapid Bay jetty, as seen from the end of the new jetty. (ABC South East SA: Caroline Horn)

Mr Corrigan said many of his international and interstate customers came to the state specifically to see leafy seadragons in the area.

"It's on a lot of people's bucket list to scuba dive and they get trained up and they come down here and they do courses," he said.

Mr Corrigan is hopeful the area, with its historically large colony of leafy seadragons, will recover from the current algal bloom and said it could even help repopulate the species in other areas.

Hopes for future after bloom

Catherine Larkin, a marine biologist and operations manager for the conservation organisation AusOcean, also believes the area under the old Rapid Bay jetty is one of South Australia's best dive sites.

Catherine Larkin says Rapid Bay is an important training site for divers. (ABC South East SA: Caroline Horn)

"I don't think people realise how important this site is for divers," she said.

" It's one of the only sites in the state where you are pretty much guaranteed to see the leafy seadragon. "

A petition created by AusOcean, with the support of the Scuba Divers Federation of South Australia, has already attracted more than 1,700 signatures.

Ms Larkin said on her last dive, shortly before the storm damage, it was apparent the site had been impacted by the algal bloom, but at that time there was still visible life in the area.

Some of the marine life under the old Rapid Bay jetty. (Supplied: Catherine Larkin)

Ms Larkin said Rapid Bay was one of only a few sites accessible to divers from shore and it was important for diver training.

She said the best area to see the marine life in the area was under the remaining T-section of the jetty.

A spokesperson for the Department for Infrastructure and Transport, which is responsible for the old and new Rapid Bay jetties, said an assessment carried out after storms in May confirmed the structure had further deteriorated.

Construction on the old jetty started in 1938. (Supplied: State Library of South Australia)

The spokesperson said the department would investigate options to reduce or remove the current 20m exclusion zone and meet with divers and interested groups to find the best way forward.

"These investigations, including the costs and viable options, are expected to be finalised in late 2025."

The investigation will also undertake contamination testing on timber and steel components of the old jetty.

New jetty also under repair

While the assessment on the old jetty is carried out, renewal work is being carried out on the adjacent "new" jetty.

Swimming and boating has been banned within 20m of the old jetty since June. (ABC South East SA: Caroline Horn)

The work includes the replacement of four ladders, repairs to steel sections where the coating has been damaged, and installation of protective wrapping on the base of some piles to prevent corrosion.

The department spokesperson said work on the new jetty, which was open and accessible to all users, was on track to be completed in mid-September.

title: 74yo swaps birthday cake for lawyer certificate
text:
Every month, hundreds of promising legal minds around the country apply to court to be admitted to practice law.

And while many are only at the start of their careers, one South Australian man has attended the ceremony before the Supreme Court on his 74th birthday.

"I've had some interesting birthdays, but this one tops the lot," he said.

Tim Looker (right) with University of South Australia chancellor John Hill. (Supplied)

Mr Looker left school at 15 and spent a few years driving tractors, before a 35-year career as a science teacher and then a stint working in local government.

He was also awarded a Medal of the Order of Australia in 2003 for his service to youth through the development of outdoor recreation and camping programs with the YMCA.

But when he retired, he was keen to pick up a hobby.

"I'm not a fisherman or a golfer, so why not go back to uni and run up a HECS debt?" he said.

Mr Looker said he did not have much of a plan for his law degree, focusing on subjects that caught his interest.

"All of a sudden I'm finished, and they sent me an email saying I'm about to graduate," he said.

Mr Looker joked that he "kept away from the pub crawls".

Tim Looker was awarded a Medal of the Order of Australia (OAM) in 2003 from then-governor Marjorie Jackson-Nelson. (Supplied)

The most recent available national data from the federal education department found around 3,300 students over 60 started a higher education degree in 2023, making up about 0.05 per cent of new students — a rate that has remained steady for the past decade.

And Law Council of Australia data from last year showed about 1 per cent of lawyers in South Australia were still practising past the age of 75.

While the South Australian Law Society could not confirm if Mr Looker was the oldest new lawyer in the state's history, president Marissa Mackie commended him for his pursuit.

"Mr Looker's worldly experience and history of community service, combined with his newly acquired legal credentials, will be ideal for his role in enhancing access to justice for those who need it most," she said.

'Very proud' moment for family and friends

Lawyers-to-be need a current lawyer to vouch for them at their admission ceremony and for Mr Looker, that lawyer was Richard Tran.

"It's a ceremony role, but it's really meaningful," Mr Tran said.

Richard Tran met Tim Looker at university. (Supplied)

The pair met in law school and, despite the 50-year age gap, formed a bond.

"He's always been caring towards me, taught me things about fixing cars, like little stuff that fathers teach their son," Mr Tran, who moved to Australia from Vietnam in 2017, said.

Mr Looker taught Mr Tran to drive and said he "sort of adopted him as my fourth child".

Richard Tran says Mr Looker has taught him a lot. (ABC News: Marco Catalano)

Mr Looker said he does not intend to make a living as a lawyer, but will continue to volunteer at a not-for-profit legal service.

"My degree will be applied to helping those who are disadvantaged," he said.

"I'll do that as long as I'm able and don't lose the plot."

His dad, Don Looker — who is 102 and served in World War II — said he was shocked when he found out his son was studying again and noted how special the timing of the admission ceremony was.

Don Looker (right) says he's "very proud" of Tim. (Supplied)

"I think it's quite meritorious," Don said.

"It's a great achievement and I'm very proud of him."

His daughter, Kate Looker, said she boasts about her dad to everyone — and joked she has big shoes to fill.

"It makes me feel like I haven't achieved much, but it also means that I have a lot of time to achieve things," she said.

"I'm just incredibly proud."

Tim Looker with daughter Kate, who says she's "incredibly proud" of her dad. (ABC News: Marco Catalano)

Mr Looker said he hoped he can inspire older people to never give up on life.

"Do not talk yourself into old age, there is always something new and exciting out there to do," he said.

"Don't stop."

title: 'Look at my highlight reels': Irankunda opens English account with wondergoal
text:
Socceroo teen star Nestory Irankunda has continued his terrific start to life in England, netting his first goal for Watford via a sensational free kick.

The 19-year-old Tanzanian-born winger, who starred at Adelaide United but didn't make the grade at German champions Bayern Munich, curled a glorious 25-yard free-kick home to give the second-tier Hornets the lead at Swansea in the 35th minute of their 1-1 draw.

But he had to persuade Moussa Sissoko to let him take the kick, suggesting that his experienced French international captain really ought to take a look at his highlights reels, which feature similar strikes when he was at the Reds.

The belting strike capped another impressive performance from Irankunda, who proved a real handful for the Swansea defence, including fellow Socceroo Cameron Burgess, all afternoon with his speed and trickery until he was brought off just before the hour as a precaution when he appeared to suffer a hamstring knock.

Snapped up from the Bundesliga giants on a five-year deal, Irankunda had already made a big impression, and was quick to tell reporters how his ambition was to "make the crowd go wild" at Vicarage Road.

He did just that when winning the free kick just after the half-hour, before picking himself up to whip the ball up and over the Welsh side's wall and into the left-hand corner.

"Oh, my. I've scored some good goals but I reckon that could be in my top five," Irankunda said.

With usual free-kick taker Imran Louza out injured, he took his chance.

"Obviously, you have to ask for permission, and I said to Moussa, 'I feel confident in taking a free kick'," he said.

"He asked me a couple times, 'are you sure you can take free kicks?', I said, 'yeah, go look at my highlight reels!' Then after that, I just put it into the corner …"

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

When Irankunda went off, soon after being fouled by Swansea's new signing Marko Stamenic, Watford's impetus seemed to be lost and Zan Vipotnik came off the bench for the Swans to rescue a point with an 82nd-minute goal.

Irankunda has been enjoying being back in the thick of the action after his confidence took a bit of a hit in Germany.

"It's been good," he said.

"I feel like myself again, a whole lot more confident. It's fun to come to training every day. I love playing here."

He's not the only Australian making an early-season mark in English soccer's second tier.

Portsmouth midfielder Adrian Segecic again impressed in a 1-1 draw at West Brom, while Sammy Silvera continues to shine for Middlesbrough as a 2-1 win at Norwich took the side joint-top on a maximum nine points from three games, alongside Stoke, who won 2-1 at Southampton.

AAP

title: Staff safety concerns raised over supermarket bag checks, security gates
text:
Sadie Simmonds was just 18 years old when she was attacked at work while conducting a bag check.

She was working at Aldi in West Footscray and asked a woman at the check-out if she could inspect her bag.

The customer threw a carton of milk at her face, Ms Simmonds said, and shoved her so forcefully she fell backwards out of her seat, and on to her back on the floor.

She said what happened to her was not out of the ordinary.

"I have seen a co-worker have to get stitches because he was so brutally bashed," she said.

Former Aldi worker Sadie Simmonds says she always felt an "impending sense of doom" that she might be attacked. (ABC News: Patrick Rocca)

It made going to work a weekly struggle.

"There was always this impending sense of doom that at any moment you could be attacked."

Ms Simmonds, now 20, said it was the moment she decided to join the retail workers union.

About 18 months later, working as the health and safety representative at a different Aldi in Keilor Downs, Ms Simmonds handed out a trades hall safety survey to try and gather evidence for her employer that staff did not feel safe at work.

Ms Simmonds was fired for allegedly breaching company policy. (ABC News: Patrick Rocca)

When she went back to the staff with the results, she was fired for allegedly breaching company policy.

"I just wanted to draw attention to the issues retail workers face. We have been seeing heightened levels of aggression and violence in stores," she said.

The union filed an unfair dismissal case in the Federal Court on Ms Simmonds's behalf on Thursday.

" I want retail workers to know they're not alone in this ... They don't actually deserve to be treated like this and legally they should not be treated like this. "

Ms Simmonds hopes her case will lead Aldi to stop mandatory bag checks by staff.

On Friday, a worker from Woolworths at Werribee Plaza in Melbourne's west lodged a case backed by the union in the Fair Work Commission.

They claimed bag checks and new security gates at self-serve check-outs had created "specific and significant risks of customer and offender aggression" by "locking abusive … and violent offenders into a confined space with employees and customers".

The worker and the union want Woolworths to back down on mandatory bag checks and remove security gates.

The union has called on Woolworths to stop mandatory bag checks by staff. (ABC News)

Retail and Fast Food Worker Union secretary Josh Cullinan said staff were increasingly afraid to go to work.

"Bag checks are likely to lead to forms of violence," he said.

"Even if it's one in a 100, they've got so many customers [to serve] they have to worry every single time they look in someone's bag: what's going to come next, is it going to be abuse, is it going to be harassment, is it going to be a punch?"

Mr Cullinan said body-worn cameras rolled out by Coles and Woolworths also put staff at risk because they had to tell customers during bag checks when they began recording.

"It's about putting staff on the front line to stop stock loss, it's not about safety, it's about theft. Having to have a camera strapped to your body that is in your face … is just asking for trouble. These steps need to stop."

A Coles worker wears a body-worn camera in 2023. (ABC News)

According to documents from the ACCC supermarkets inquiry last year, abuse, threats, intimidation, assaults and other workplace violence involving Woolworths staff had increased year-on-year since 2014.

Records of a point-of-sale "verbal abuse tool" that allows Woolworths staff to push a button and record verbal abuse instances found they were occurring almost 700 times a week on average, impacting 430 staff members across 233 stores.

During the inquiry, Coles reported that from June 2013 to March 2024, about 8,000 cases of customer violence or aggression towards staff were reported.

Data from Victoria Police also found retail theft was up 36 per cent across the state in the past year.

"By putting in place structures to limit stock loss [from] theft, [supermarkets] have been putting our members on the front line and that's what's causing a lot of this hostility," Mr Cullinan said.

Police Minister Anthony Carbines says the government will soon introduce retail worker harm legislation. (ABC News)

Police Minister Anthony Carbines said the government would be introducing retail worker harm legislation this year, "that brings serious consequences to those who do harm and assault retail workers".

"We need to send a very clear message to the community and reflect the community's expectations that young people and all people who work in our retail sector are safe."

An Aldi spokesperson said the company valued its people and was "committed to their health and safety".

"This matter is currently going through legal proceedings so we cannot comment on the specifics of it."

A Woolworths spokesperson said the company treated "the safety of our team members and customers very seriously".

title: Regional city fears reputational hit over writers' festival fallout
text:
Bendigo residents believe the recent controversy surrounding the city's signature writers' festival will damage its reputation for years to come.

More than 50 writers and hosts withdrew from the Bendigo Writers Festival after organiser Greater Bendigo City Council sent a code of conduct to participants.

The code stipulated writers should "avoid language or topics that could be considered inflammatory, divisive or disrespectful".

It also required guests speaking at La Trobe University-sponsored sessions to comply with Universities Australia's definition of anti-Semitism.

The move has largely been criticised by free speech advocates.

Bendigo council and La Trobe University have not commented on what prompted them to send the code two days before the festival's opening night.

Hard work undone

Anthony Radford is a founding member of Believe in Bendigo, a campaign championing diversity in the regional Victorian city following anti-mosque protests in 2015.

He said the festival fallout had "without a doubt" undone some of the work to restore the reputational damage of those protests.

"Ten years after that to have more national headlines about race in Bendigo is horrible," he said.

" We want people to come to this city and celebrate these events, not boycott these events. "

Mr Radford said the city had more to offer.

"The [writers' festival] was a way we could promote the city, and the harmony and cultural attributes this city has, and I just feel what happened over the past weekend has potentially been the result of people not understanding that."

Business owner Georgie Pell says the usually busy writers' festival weekend was quiet this year. (ABC Central Victoria: Emile Pavlich)

Businesses disappointed

Multiple businesses on Bendigo's main street opposite the arts precinct had ordered extra stock for the weekend.

Georgie Pell's clothing store Pink Honey was one of those businesses.

"It's usually a really happening buzz, but it was very, very quiet," she said.

" I felt like many people boycotted the event and didn't come [to Bendigo]. "

Meanwhile, two hospitality businesses near festival venues decided to close on the Sunday due to a lack of foot traffic.

Hayley Tibbett says the festival was not a great result for the local economy. (Supplied: Be.Bendigo)

Hayley Tibbett, chief executive of Bendigo's chamber of commerce, Be.Bendigo, said it was a difficult situation and not a great result for the region's economy.

"It's not really the look that we want for our city either," she said.

City of Greater Bendigo Mayor Andrea Metcalf told ABC Radio Central Victoria Breakfast it was disappointing author cancellations had become the main narrative at a storytelling event.

Mayor Andrea Metcalf says it wasn't the writers' festival the city had hoped for. (ABC Central Victoria: Shannon Schubert)

"It isn't about the city being the story," she said.

" Writers' festivals are risky and they exist to push boundaries, they are there for debate. "

In a statement, Greater Bendigo City Council said it intended to "honour the financial commitments" to local businesses.

"The city will reach out to those businesses to chat with them about what that loss looks like," Cr Metcalf told the ABC.

Budget papers reveal $2.3 million was allocated for Bendigo Venue and Events in 2024/25, which is a local government arm in charge of all major events.

The council declined to respond to questions about how much taxpayer funds had been allocated to the festival.

Writer Di Dempsey is worried about the festival's future. (ABC News)

Future uncertain

Greater Bendigo City Council is yet to confirm if the festival will return in 2026.

Bendigo writer Di Dempsey, who attended the festival while expressing solidarity with those boycotting it, said she was "terrified" it would shut down permanently.

"I really hope they don't," she said.

"I hope they use this publicity as a way of turning it around and … say, 'We're not going to let this happen again.'"

Mr Radford agreed and said it was an opportunity for the festival to come back bigger than ever in 2026.

"A festival that celebrates everything writers love and everything that's really positive about Bendigo," he said.

title: 'Could've gone either way': Injury-hit Wallabies fall short of second-straight South Africa heist
text:
James O'Connor has missed three crucial late kicks as the injury-hit Wallabies suffered an agonising 30-22 loss to South Africa in Cape Town.

The Wallabies entered Saturday night's (Sunday morning AEST) Rugby Championship match looking to win back-to-back Tests against the Springboks in South Africa for the first time since 1963 following last week's famous 38-22 triumph in Johannesburg.

South Africa led 20-7 approaching half-time, but the Wallabies hit back hard after the break and closed the margin to one point in the 68th minute when reserve hooker Brandon Paenga-Amosa touched down following a successful rolling maul.

O'Connor slightly slipped during his conversion attempt, pulling the kick to the near side in what proved to be a major missed opportunity.

South Africa extended their lead 30-22 in the 75th minute, but O'Connor had a chance to close the gap back to five points three minutes later with a 25m penalty from a slight angle.

O'Connor pushed that kick to the right this time, and his 50m penalty attempt in the 80th minute, which would have given Australia a losing bonus point, fell short.

Yet it was still another brave and encouraging performance from the Wallabies, who were again hamstrung by more injuries.

Tom Wright (left) was forced off the ground after just four minutes of action. (Getty Images: Grant Pitcher)

A devastated Tom Wright lasted just four minutes before going off with a left knee injury, while scrumhalf Nic White was forced off in the 13th minute with concussion after his head was slammed into the turf during a slinging tackle.

Prop Taniela Tupou dislocated his left pinky shortly before half-time, and outside centre Joseph-Aukuso Suaalii was subbed out at the break after an apparent head knock.

It came on top of the Wallabies losing skipper Harry Wilson (knee), James Slipper (concussion) and Dylan Pietsch (broken jaw) last week.

"I'm super proud of my boys," stand-in Wallabies skipper Fraser McReight said.

" We lost a few good men out there, and under a bit of adversity we fought right until the end. It could have gone either way. "

South Africa scored two penalties inside the opening six minutes of the match before the Wallabies struck back through debutant Corey Toole in the eighth minute.

White was the mastermind behind the try, with his quick tap-and-go and subsequent dribble kick allowing Toole to run on to the bouncing ball.

South Africa replied soon after, with Handre Pollard's cross-kick finding an open Canan Moodie for an easy try.

McReight was denied a 13th-minute try due to an earlier knock-on, and Australia were left to rue twice turning down kickable penalties in favour of going for touch.

Corey Toole took just eight minutes to score his first Wallabies try on debut. (Getty Images: Ashley Vlotman)

South Africa's defence held firm on each occasion, and the scoreline read 20-7 when forward Kwagga Smith barged over in the 35th minute.

O'Connor's penalty after the half-time siren reduced the deficit to 10 points at the break.

Australia struck first in the second half when O'Connor's chaos kick couldn't be controlled by Springboks winger Moodie, allowing Max Jorgensen to swoop on the loose ball and race over.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

A Wallabies win in Cape Town for the first time in 33 years was on the cards when Paenga-Amosa scored with 12 minutes remaining, but O'Connor's conversion miss was a huge turning point.

But there were many positives for the visitors, not least the debut of Toole, whose extreme pace and no-fear attack were a constant threat.

"I know it is a loss, but it was three tries apiece with a team that got destabilised early on. It does give belief," Wallabies coach Joe Schmidt said.

"I feel like we have built some belief. It is a group of players I am enjoying working with immensely. They enjoy their work and the way we are trying to play.

"I have never had so many messages of support for Australian rugby as I have seen this week."

AAP

title: AFL LIVE: GWS host St Kilda to kick off Super Sunday
text:
If GWS expect an easy win over St Kilda, Giants star Tom Green reckons they’d be kidding themselves.

The Giants only need to flick to last year in the history books to be reminded of how easily Ross Lyon’s Saints can upset the finals order.

It was round 24, 2024 and Carlton needed to beat St Kilda to seal their top-eight spot.

Instead, Jack Higgins’ last-gasp goal fired the Saints to an upset two-point win that opened the door for Fremantle, who were playing in the last game of the home-and-away season.

Tom Green. Credit: Getty Images

The Dockers ultimately lost to Port Adelaide but it remains a cautionary tale as 12th-placed St Kilda seek to play finals spoilers at Engie Stadium on Sunday, when GWS look to secure a home elimination final.

Now boasting the signature of in-demand talent Nasiah Wanganeen-Milera, Lyon’s side are gunning for a fifth straight win.

The Giants, one of four teams that started the final round on 60 points, can finish as high as fifth or as low as eighth, depending on how results fall.

If that wasn’t enough motivation, Giants academy product and defender Harry Himmelberg will also mark his 200-game milestone.

“If we think we’re going to roll in and just get a result, I think we’d be kidding ourselves,” Giants midfielder Green told AAP. “There’s a lot to play for. We won’t be taking the game lightly.”

Curbing Wanganeen-Milera’s impact on the game will be No.1 on the agenda for the Giants.

The 22-year-old has had a devastating effect on opponents since being moved from half-back into the midfield this year.

Deploying Toby Bedford as a tagger is a lever GWS coach Adam Kingsley could pull, though the midfielder-forward hasn’t been used recently in that role.

If it were up to Green, it wouldn’t be him either.

“He’s (Wanganeen-Milera) probably too quick for me,” Green joked. “He’s playing a little bit of everywhere and has a bit of a license to go and influence the game in all parts of the ground. He will be a tough prospect to stop and if we can go some way to dealing with him, I’m sure that’ll help us get close to a good result.”

GWS are unchanged for Sunday’s clash after initial hopes of defender Jack Buckley (calf) playing his first game since round 20. Lethal small forward Brent Daniels, absent since round 14, will make his return from an adductor injury through the VFL.

St Kilda made one change, with last week’s debutant Alex Dodson making way for Isaac Keeler.
